Description: Juglet of straw-tempered Nile silt pottery with flat base, ovoid body, short inset neck and everted roll over rim (chipped), long spout applied to one shoulder; exterior coated with red wash.
Curator's comments: Fancy ware F58g in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921); see also W.M.F Petrie and A.C. Mace, Diospolis Parva, London (1901), pl. xiv. F53a var. Spouted juglets represent influence and contacts with Mesopotamia where vessels of this shape were more common; however the clay and the manufacturing methods show that this pot was made in Egypt.
